title: A Diagnosis Brings C.T.E. Into American Pro Soccer
abstract: Scott Vermillion, a former college star who played four seasons in M.L.S., died in 2020. He is the first American professional soccer player with a public case of C.T.E.

title: Serena Williams Exits Wimbledon in the First Round, Again
abstract: Williams, who had not competed in singles on tour since withdrawing from Wimbledon last year with an injury, lost in three sets to Harmony Tan of France.

multimedia.caption: Serena Williams during her first-round match against Harmony Tan.

title: Like Most Good Sequels, Atlanta Has Stuck With What Worked
abstract: Dansby Swanson is leading the way for a team that started slowly but is now hot on the Mets’ heels. If it feels familiar, it should.

multimedia.caption: After a slow start, Dansby Swanson is turning heads as one of the most valuable shortstops in baseball.
After a slow start, Dansby Swanson is turning heads as one of the most valuable shortstops in baseball.

title: Berrettini Out of Wimbledon as Coronavirus Enters the Draw
abstract: The exit of Matteo Berrettini, who reached the men’s singles final last year, came one day after Marin Cilic withdrew after also testing positive for the virus.

title: With So Many Suspensions After a Brawl, M.L.B. Staggers Them
abstract: Manager Phil Nevin’s 10-game ban was among the 47 games of suspensions the league handed out after a brawl between Los Angeles and Seattle.

title: Kyrie Irving Decides to Opt Into a Fourth Season With the Nets
abstract: Irving was eligible for a maximum contract extension, but he and the Nets did not reach an agreement on one. Once he officially opts in, they will have until the end of June 2023 to negotiate an extension.

multimedia.caption: Nets guard Kyrie Irving, left, showed glimpses of his star-caliber play in 2021-22 but played only 29 games in the regular season.

title: Not Just a Tennis Podcast, but Rather ‘The’ Tennis Podcast
abstract: It started around David Law’s parents’ dining room table. A decade later, “The Tennis Podcast” is the conscience of the game and how the sport communicates with itself.

multimedia.caption: “The Tennis Podcast” hosts recorded an episode at the French Open with Pam Shriver, a former player who is a television analyst, as a guest.

title: As N.F.L. Mulls Watson Case, an Accuser Adds Suit Against His Old Team
abstract: One of the 24 women who sued Watson for sexual misconduct claimed in a lawsuit filed Monday that the N.F.L. team enabled their star quarterback’s alleged behavior.

title: Is That Steph Curry … or a Work of Art?
abstract: This Instagram account will change how you see basketball.

title: The Eliud Kipchoge Ripple Effect: Sub-7 and Sub-8-Hour Triathlons
abstract: Kipchoge’s sub-two-hour marathon in 2019 inspired efforts to reach previously unimaginable times for men and women in the triathlon.

multimedia.caption: Nicola Spirig punctured her lung and broke her collarbone and ribs while training in February. She was one of four athletes to participate in the Sub7Sub8 event in early June.

title: A Soccer Team’s Success Puts Its Small Arab Village on the Map
abstract: Established in 2016, Maccabi Bnei Reineh is the talk of Israel’s top division after completing a quick rise. Its founders say its presence represents something far more important.

title: How a Tennis Nerd Gave Serena and Venus Williams a New Lease on the Game
abstract: Eric Hechtman, a club professional from Miami, has signed on to help two champions chase success far beyond the usual finish line of a tennis career.

title: Marlin Briscoe, Pioneering Black Quarterback, Dies at 76
abstract: He became the first Black starting quarterback of the Super Bowl era in the 1960s, but prejudiced thinking by coaches stifled his trajectory at the position.

title: The New (Cushy Seats) and the Familiar (Novak, Nerves) Mix at Wimbledon
abstract: One hundred years after the opening of Centre Court, it’s a season of change at the All England Club, what with the barring of Russian players and a new set of green doors.

title: Once an ‘Easy Way Out’ for Equality, Women’s Soccer Is Now a U.S. Force
abstract: After Title IX passed in 1972, administrators found soccer to be a cheap way to comply. Participation rates for girls and women soared in high schools, universities and club teams.

title: As Wimbledon Begins, an Era of Sports Free of Bans and Boycotts Ends
abstract: For decades, sports has avoided punishing athletes for the actions of their countries. Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has put an end to that.

title: Colorado Avalanche Unseat Tampa Bay to Win the Stanley Cup
abstract: The Avalanche took the lead in the second period to win their first title since 2001 and end the Lightning’s bid for a third consecutive title. They did it convincingly, never facing elimination.
kicker: Avalanche 2, Lightning 1 | Colorado Wins Stanley Cup, 4-2

title: Astros Give Yankees a Tough Series, and a Measuring Stick
abstract: Aaron Judge carried his team to victory on Sunday, but in a four-game draw, Houston proved the Yankees can’t just coast to the pennant.

title: Schauffele Holds Off Theegala to Win Travelers Championship
abstract: Xander Schauffele nearly let a three-shot lead slip away, but a birdie on No. 18 gave him a two-stroke victory over Sahith Theegala and J.T. Poston.

abstract: By design, Djokovic usually does not play grass-court events before Wimbledon, and he has won five times with that tactic. Nadal, necessitated by injury, is on the same track this year.

title: Once Again, Tennis Is Disrupted by Politics
abstract: The sport has a long history of disputes, especially over apartheid. This year Wimbledon has banned Russian and Belarusian players.
